key_points: Facebook bans creation of new events near the White House, U.S. Capitol, and state capitols until after Biden's inauguration.
The social media giant will review and remove inauguration-related events that violate its policies.
Facebook aims to block U.S.-based events created by accounts outside of the U.S.
The company is monitoring for signs of violence or threats in Washington, D.C., and across all states.
Facebook continues to pause political advertising and restricts certain features for users who frequently violate policies.
The Department of Homeland Security has indicated that domestic extremists pose a significant threat to the inauguration.
DHS has issued warnings about violence against federal buildings, law enforcement, and public officials.
Social media platforms enhance content moderation following the Capitol attack on January 6.
Twitter and Amazon have taken steps against content believed to incite violence.
Airbnb cancels all Washington D.C. reservations for inauguration week due to security concerns.
